abstract.p: Teresa Carpenter article on a memorable visit to Greece when she was young (M)

block.p: One spring when I was young, I quit a job, converted my assets to traveler's checks and took a three-month holiday in Europe. As this mad interlude drew to a close, I found myself in Athens with $200 to my name. In light of my reduced circumstances, I checked into the Pankration Pension for Young Ladies, a clean, well-lighted dormitory offering bed and shower for 90 cents a night.

There, I met three spinsters from Akron, Ohio. They took a kindly interest in me, and one night, when I was running a fever, they shared their supplies of bottled water. The following morning, though I was still wobbly, they insisted I accompany them to a summer festival on the Saronic Gulf. So we set out in their rented Volvo across the Isthmus of Corinth, stopping for a swim in the Aegean.

One spring when I was young, I quit a job, converted my assets to traveler's checks and took a three-month holiday in Europe. As this mad interlude drew to a close, I found myself in Athens with $200 to my name. In light of my reduced circumstances, I checked into the Pankration Pension for Young Ladies, a clean, well-lighted dormitory offering bed and shower for 90 cents a night.

There, I met three spinsters from Akron, Ohio. They took a kindly interest in me, and one night, when I was running a fever, they shared their supplies of bottled water. The following morning, though I was still wobbly, they insisted I accompany them to a summer festival on the Saronic Gulf. So we set out in their rented Volvo across the Isthmus of Corinth, stopping for a swim in the Aegean.

It was past dusk when we reached the town of Epidaurus. The driver, Johanna, parked the car in a lot at the foot of a grove of old cedars and beckoned us to follow her up a mountain path. It was perfectly quiet, except for the crunch of pine needles beneath our feet, and it was very dark. We crested a bluff and below us spread a huge and ancient amphitheater ablaze with lights and packed with 14,000 spectators.

The play had started and by the time we found seats, Orestes had begun his flight from the Furies, played by a chorus in tattered gray robes. They turned the robes inside out in one graceful gesture, revealing pink undercloaks as they changed into Eumenides.
The dialogue was in Greek. I don't know whether I was hallucinating or whether I was under some enchantment of an August night in the Peloponnesus, but I understood every word.
Teresa Carpenter is writing a book about a political kidnapping during the Theodore Roosevelt administration.
